By Ujjwal Narayan
NewsRise
Adds Delhi High Court hearing details
NEW DELHI (Feb 8) -- India’s Supreme Court today rejected Amazon’s plea to file a written submission after the top court reserved its order on Future Group’s prayer for permission to go ahead with Reliance Industries' acquisition deal.

“You want to complicate matters, drag on hearings; best not to list these matters, it appears to be a luxurious litigation,” Chief Justice N.V. Ramana observed.

In 2019, Amazon invested $200 million in Future Coupons for a 49% stake, which gave the U.S. company a 7.3% foothold in flagship Future Retail. However, the two companies fell out after debt-laden Future Group agreed to sell its retail, wholesale, warehousing, and logistics businesses in August 2020 to billionaire Mukesh Ambani’s Reliance Industries in a $3.4 billion deal. The deal with Reliance is crucial to Future Group, which is on the brink of liquidation.

Amazon tried to block the deal by getting a freeze order from Singapore arbitration court. Future Group’s prospective sell out to Reliance threatens the U.S. company’s dominance in India.

The Competition Commission of India kept its approval for the 2019 deal between Amazon and Future on hold, accusing the U.S. e-commerce company of hiding information while seeking regulatory approval.

Meanwhile, the Delhi High Court today asked both Amazon and Future Retail to give details of all pending issues between the two groups and clubbed cases, citing an apex court order.

“Three different single-judge benches were hearing cases. The Supreme Court order mandated clubbing of pending issues, both parties to give small note of four pages,” Justice C Hari Shankar said.

The court will hear the pending cases on Feb. 11, the judge said.
